captions.text:
>> Today, I'm going to deliver a news to
Professor

Andrei Linde, who is the founding father
of inflation.

So inflation is the theory about the bang
of the big bang,

it explains why we have all this stuff in
the universe.

So today I'm going to tell him, our
experiment, Bicep two based

at South Pole, has found the smoking gun
evidence of inflation.
He has no idea that I'm coming.
>> So I have a surprise for you.
>> It's Phi Sigma at point two.
Jake, Jake, Jake, Jake, Jake, Jake, Jake.

>> Phi Sigma as clear as day are at point
two.
>> R point two plus minus point alt five.
It's probably some kind of delivery.
Yeah, I ordered something [LAUGH] 30 years ago.

>> We are talking right now about the
billionth of the billionth

of the millionth of a million of a second,
after the big bang.

So we see the face of the big bang, it is
an image of these gravitational waves

which is purely quantum gravity feature
of, of what was produced in the big bang.

So this, is the remaining part of the
story.

>> If this is true, this is a moment of
understanding of nature.

Of such a magnitude, that it just
overwhelms.

Let's, let's just hope that this is not a
trick.
I always live with this feeling.

What if I, I believe into this, just
because it is beautiful?
Thank you so much, for doing it for us.

>> For more, please visit us at
stanford.edu.

title: Stanford Professor Andrei Linde celebrates physics breakthrough

comments.author: Xiao Sun

comments.text:
The BICEP2 result was discredited by the newest Planck result, but 
premature gravitational waves as predicted by Linde et al. aren't ruled 
out. For more details, see:

www.preposterousuniverse.com/blog/2015/02/06/the-state-of-the-early-universe
﻿
comments.author: NeedsEvidence

comments.text:
+Benjamin Steber > It's so hard to believe that someone can say five sigma 
with such confidence and still be wrong.

Not really. Mistakes like these are possible when you underestimate the 
background contribution to an observation, as happened in the BICEP2 
analysis.

> It pains me to say BICEP2 will probably be remembered as a cautionary 
tale.﻿

It's an overall successful experiment with important results (note that the 
CMB resolution achieved by BICEP2 surpasses that of Planck). This one 
analysis was flawed (an honest mistake, from what I can see), and some 
collaborators withdraw their authorship to the paper (if I'm not mistaken) 
prior to the publication (wouldn't be the first time that things like this 
happens in big science collaborations). ﻿
comments.author: NeedsEvidence

comments.text:
Five sigma.  Less than 30 million to one that the results were wrong.

But Plank indicates that BICEP2 went dusting for the fingerprint of the 
universe and came back with dust.  Milky way dust which rendered the 
finding inconclusive.

It's so hard to believe that someone can say five sigma with such 
confidence and still be wrong.  It pains me to say BICEP2 will probably be 
remembered as a cautionary tale.﻿

Linde's prediction still stands but hasn't been discovered as yet. BICEP2's 
result was premature (the background due to dust was underestimated), but 
Planck did not rule out primordial gravitational waves but set an upper 
sensitivity limit.

comments.author: narmerpha menes

comments.text:
I would love nothing more than for this to be verified, but sadly, it's 
looking as though it probably isn't true.

The idea is that inflation created gravitational waves, and these waves 
polarized the CMB radiation (the radiation given off by a ~400,000 year old 
universe). However, it was shown a few months ago that it's entirely 
possible this polarization was caused by cosmic dust.

This is a great blog post about it:
http://blankonthemap.blogspot.it/2014/09/biting-dust.html﻿

comments.author: Гриша Почуев

comments.text:
Another big failure in US science now it turns out the signal is likely 
totally nonexistent following ESA's PLANCK results. This really makes 
Standford and other US Universities involved look like total frauds in the 
eyes of the world science community. Not because of the big mistake alone. 
That can sometimes happen. But especially since they immediately started to 
claim it as real scientific fact like shown in many other claims and 
comments by those involved. Shame, shame. Real shame.

And this now follows many other big embarrassments for US science in recent 
years like the NASA new life claim that turned out to be fake and based on 
completely bogus science. Like the false claims by Fermilab of a Higgs 
Boson signal just months before CERN was about to make the actual discovery 
based on much larger and more precise data sets (like here with ESA and 
Planck). Like the recent claim of 1 US and 1 Japanese university of a major 
stem cell breakthrough that turned out be a total fake and actual fraud. I 
don`t mind big mistakes. Just when things are claimed as facts so easily by 
scientists in this country. It is no wonder that Scientific American 
recently reported on the fact that many US scientists have been moving to 
Europe in the last 5 years. Where much larger projects and agencies are now 
being build in an enormous number of research fields following the success 
of first European cooperation projects like CERN. 

This really makes even more scientists not just from the US but around the 
world move to Europe where budgets and science projects are growing 
dramatically. Utterly massive projects like the HUMAN BRAIN PROJECT, the 
giant European XFEL, the giant ESS (European Spallation Source), the EU 
hosted ITER Fusion facility, the worlds largest European Extremely Large 
Telescope, the scaling up of ESA science projects to ever more fields (like 
PLANCK), the CERN expansion including LHC expansion, the giant EU SPARC 
robotic program, the absolutely incredible ELI laser program to name just a 
very few. And nothing comparable in these fields is happening in the US 
accept for James Webb, but that is a joint NASA - ESA project that will 
even be launched on a European rocket. It's like the US is standing still 
on more and more levels. And than we get these giant mistakes and false 
claims on top.﻿

comments.author: ilovesudan

comments.text:
There's been some contrfoversy that they made a mistake in their dust 
calculations, but the researchers have responded that even in the worst 
case scenario dust would not decrease the signal to a level of 
insignificance. So it's all about waiting for confirmation from the other 
experiments now - nothing has confirmed or ruled out these results yet, and 
the BICEP2 people seem to have done a very thorough job. 

I would wager that because the people working understood the significance 
of the research and spent years trying to find other explanations for the 
data - and because inflation as a cosmological model has such tremendous 
explanatory and predictive power - that they probably detected a legitimate 
signla. But we can't know until its replicated.
comments.author: ihatealigators

comments.text:
It has not been discredited, it just hasn't been confirmed yet. The 
confirmation will come by the end of October 2014.
comments.author: zombiesingularity

comments.text:
No, it's not wrong. Their conclusion was correct based on the best 
available evidence at the time. There will be another experiment that will 
yield a clearer picture of the cosmic dust that could, potentially, 
invalidate their conclusions. But only potentially. It could also bolster 
their theory and further confirm their findings. Either way, science 
marches on.

"We here in America are supporting too many of these deadbeats."

used A LOT in todays telecommunication industry. Did you know that 30-40 
years from now? Nope. 

Another grant sucking "moron" played with invisible rays. He, being 
complete idiot, of course, even called them X-rays, just in an attempt to

be used in medical applications - that's the thing that shows what's with

Maybe those beetles would be found to have some valuable compound that the

comments.text:
+Danny Criss People said (and still say) the same thing about space 
exploration. So. How do you like having cell phones, instant cross-planet 
communication, and all that juicy eastern european internet porn to whack 
off to? Pretty nice, huh? Oh, and those bug experiments you're lamenting? 
Today's studies on animals and our understanding of evolution are the 
reason we've been able to find cures to all sorts of genetic diseases. Our 
understanding of DNA, RNA and how it shapes the lives of every living thing 
on this planet is what's helping us find the cure for cancer. Have you or 
anyone you've ever loved survived getting a virus? Or have you ever gotten 
a vaccination? Do you think that not having polio is overall a pretty 
awesome aspect of your life? Better thank those beetle biologsts.  Both the 
Asian and African ones. Have you ever heard of the Black Death, which 
killed 1/4 of the world's population back in the middle ages? Well, you're 
right that beetle scientists never found the cure for that one. It was rat 
scientists. And flea scientists.

The funny thing is that the three things you mentioned are all result of 
people like biologists, physicists, and chemists. You were just too 
ignorant to know it until now.

+Danny Criss I think everything new we discover is worth it. Every bit of 
knowledge we can gather will only better us as a species. When you really 
think about it, everything in this Universe is beautiful. Galaxies, Stars 
and Planets. Seas, Storms and life itself. To think that today we live in 
the craziest most unimaginable place ever, where the particles that form

center of stars. Thoughts and ideas that spark out of nothingness, which 
then manifest into the technology we see in our every day world. 

I don't see anything better to spend the money on.

If it doesn't get me more channels on my satellite, or cures cancer, or 
makes my erection last twice as long, then good riddance. This is the kind

all. I met a "scientist" once who specialized in the study of the mating 
habits of the African horned beetle. Not the Asian horned beetle, but the 
African. He is living his life in utter peace and harmony, soaking up 
valuable grant money so desperately needed by real problems. And when one 
grant runs dry. he cons another university onto funding more of his 
"research". And there are thousands more like him out there, just kicking 
back, skating through life without a real purpose. If you're country is 
losing these purveyors of snake oil, then you are fortunate. We here in 
America are supporting too many of these deadbeats.

comments.author: Mcalister

comments.text:
Of course it does, Linde himself said it. Multiverse directly counters 
Genesis and turns Big Bang (made up by a catholic priest in compliance with 
Genesis - note capital B's, meaning The beginning of Everything, period) 
into just a bang - one of infinitely many that create universes with 
different rules ("laws"). Besides, Type II Multiverse has already been 
proven experimentally, mathematically and multi-physically: 
http://www.mynewsdesk.com/ba/pressreleases/as-big-bang-gets-downgraded-to-a-bang-the-first-scientific-proof-of-the-multiverse-claimed-975493
comments.author: Bosnian Royal Family

comments.text:
So sad. Read today that they think the BICEP experiment was incorrect or 
flawed. Not in a bitter just trying to disprove someone way but in a really 
sad and depressing we were wrong in our results. Not to say the theory is 
wrong just the experiment. :-( Very, very, sad day. :-(﻿
comments.author: Matthew Rader

comments.text:
Not so fast, there's nothing wrong with BICEP. It's just politicking: 
papists trying to kill Multiverse and thus save Genesis, by making #BICEP2 
inconclusive (so to allow for "heaven above" fable). They pulled the same 
trick with so-called "Jesuit science" of seismology -- made it 
"inconclusive" so to enable "hell below" fable. They think they are the 
owners of those two realms (mankind's captors), so it was their pries who 
invented cosmology itself by creating the Big Bang (note capital B's) which 
Linde now turned into just a bang that created infinitely many universes 
with own sets of rules ("laws").
